choices.C: Use a SAQL query leveraging the "fill" statement with a "partition" parameter.
choices.A: Use a "Compare Table" and add a column leveraging the "Running Total" function.
choices.B: Use a "Compare Table" and use the "Show summary" option.
choices.D: Use a SAQL query to create fake rows for any data that is missing data from the dataset.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
A shipping company created a dataset, "Book11," containing budget per region per month for the first six months of 2018. The dataset is shown in the graphic.
Now, they want to create a lens showing the total budget for each region for each month. Every combination of region and month must be shown in the lens, even if there is no data.
How can a Tableau CRM Consultant help this company build this lens?

discussion.content: C is correct

I review the questions in my dev org. I still cannot tell for sure the right answer.

A : No, running total is not working because it needs 2 measures and 1 dimension. Here Date is not a measure (but a date) and the function is greyed out (even though one could extract the month in a dataflow/recipe).
B : Maybe. I can obtain what is descried using the "show subtotal" setting of Compare table with the proper grouping, or pivot table. However "show subtotal" is different than "show summary" in description. I don't know what they refer to with "show summary".
C : Maybe. I guess It could work indeed and fill the gaps (there could be a date gap, where no data is reported for specific month, for example). I realize that this "fill" function is what should be used for the 1st challenge of the superbadge, by the way.
D : I might miss the point here but why create a fake row for a missing data, it makes no sense...

Correct!
https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.bi_dev_guide_saql.meta/bi_dev_guide_saql/bi_saql_statement_fill.htm

questions.question_text:
A Tableau CRM team reports that when they start their dataflow it runs successfully with no errors or warnings, but one of the fields does not return values when it is queried.
What can be the origin of this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I think the answer is D. The Security User Profile is what is used when querying the data for this. If the value was not there, it would just return null.

Selected Answer: B
B, in other situations there would be an error.

comments.content: Correcting to A... Integration User doesn't have access to the field. Such situation is also not triggering an error.

discussion.content: I'd say this is D

B or C
B. The field does not contain any data in Salesforce: If the field does not contain any data in Salesforce, it will not return any values when queried, regardless of whether the dataflow runs successfully or not.
C. The user who runs the dataflow does not have access to the field: If the user who runs the dataflow does not have access to the field, the dataflow will run successfully but will not retrieve any values for that field.
A and D are less likely to be the issue since they relate to access profiles that are not directly related to the dataflow or query. However, it's still possible that these access profiles are preventing the field from being queried if they restrict access to the data source that the dataflow is pulling data from.
Question was on exam 21 August 2022.

choices.B: The field does not contain any data in Salesforce.
choices.D: The "Security User Profile" does not have access to the field.
choices.A: The "Integration User Profile" does not have access to the field.
choices.C: The user who runs the dataflow does not have access to the field.

choices.B: Update the Model settings for the models and set a terminal state filter.
choices.D: Run the models against the dataset used to create the stories.
choices.C: Run the models against all the data currently in org to calculate their performance.
choices.A: Update the Models settings for the models and add a prediction field.

questions.question_text:
Universal Containers (UC) has 10 models currently in production that are being used to predict across their org, UC is interested in understanding how well these
10 models are performing.
What are the steps required to achieve this?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer! Ignore my previous comment.
Also i think A and B are most relevant if we talk about write back the wordins is bad in this question

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer

Selected Answer: B
A : adding a prediction does not assess performance of already existing models
B : yes, enable monitoring performance, set terminal state, click on ANALYZE ACCURACY
C : not ALL the data, only subset determined by terminal state
D : that does not bring more information than already obtained

According to this Salesforce help article both A and B seems to be correct. I hate the bad wording of these questions...

https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=sf.bi_edd_model_manager_accuracy.htm&type=5

The article states that you first create a prediction field and then you set a terminal state by selecting an outcome field.
Question was on exam 21 August 2022.

Selected Answer: A
https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.232.0.bi_dev_guide_saql.meta/bi_dev_guide_saql/bi_saql_functions_coalesce.htm
A. Coalesce() is the correct one

Correct! A. coalesce() can be used for replacing a null value with another value. 
https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.232.0.bi_dev_guide_saql.meta/bi_dev_guide_saql/bi_saql_functions_coalesce.htm

FYI, D. replace() are incorrect because it always returns a null value if the input is a null value.
Question was on exam 21 August 2022.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Universal Containers has a dashboard for Sales Managers to visualize the YoY Growth of their customers. The formula used is: YoY = [(This Year - Last Year) /
Last Year] %
Based on the graphic, when there is no account in the Last Year column, the YoY Growth shows null results. The Sales Managers want to replace it with 100% value.
What is the correct function to use?

Using the Setup menu, the Universal Containers company activated data sync (replication) in the Tableau CRM settings. After running the sync, they notice that the aggregate sum of a field within their dataset is different than what they manually calculated by summing the same data in the Salesforce object from which the dataset was populated.
Which two differences in the newly synced data can explain this? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
I believe E is correct instead of C: E. There are widgets that cannot be displayed on mobile layouts.
Certain widgets may not be able to be displayed on mobile layouts due to space constraints or differences in mobile device capabilities. The consultant should consider which widgets will work best on mobile devices.

A. Differences involving trigger-updated fields: If there are any triggers set up on the Salesforce object that modify the data in a way that affects the field being summed, the data sync may not reflect those changes. The sync may not trigger the same logic as the Salesforce object does when the data is updated.

D. Differences involving formula fields: Formula fields may also contribute to the difference between the synced data and the manually calculated data. If the formula field uses a different logic or references different fields than what was used to manually calculate the data, then the sum may be different.

B. Differences involving permanently deleted records: The difference in the sum of a field within the dataset and the manually calculated data would not be explained by differences involving permanently deleted records. If a record is permanently deleted, it would not be included in either the synced data or the manually calculated data, so it would not affect the sum of the field in question. Therefore, B is not a likely explanation for the discrepancy between the two sums.

Selected Answer: BD
B and D are the correct answers. 

Incremental sync doesn’t update records that are excluded through Data Sync filters, and it doesn't remove hard-deleted (permanently) records. Also, run full sync for objects containing formula fields. With incremental sync, formula fields can become out of sync with your synced object.

https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=sf.bi_extract_data_incrementally_in_replication.htm&type=5

Correct! B and D.
https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=sf.bi_extract_data_incrementally_in_replication.htm&type=5
Question was on exam 21 August 2022.
